channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: A job with real flexibility. 100% remote Perl position
item.description: As one of the most popular open-source ticketing systems on the planet, this team knows what it takes to attract organizations of all sizes. Looking for a Perl developer who has Mason, Moose, Mojolicious and experience with ticketing systems.

item.title: Someone left the awesome job machine on again… UK remote Perl job
item.description: This company offers the perfect blend of creativity and process. They’ve been around long enough to know what they’re doing, but they thrive on innovation and aren’t stuck doing things the same way just because that’s how it was done before. You’ll have the opportunity to try new things, particularly on Hacker Days, where programmers have the chance to work on features of their choice.

item.title: Get your foot in the door! UK/EU Remote Jr. Perl Developer
item.description: We know that a lack of commercial experience doesn’t always reflect skill level, know-how, or programming brilliance. You know your stuff. You’re keen to grow and learn. You know that if someone would only just give you a chance, and let you in the door, you could really shine!

item.title: Make a Difference AND a Paycheque. 100% remote (within the UK) Mid-level Perl developer role
item.description: If you’ve got experience with Python, so much the better, but Perl is a must-have for this role. You’ll be a whiz with databases like PostgreSQL and MySQL, and you’ll write tidy, easily-maintained HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. Technical skills are important, but they aren’t the whole picture. If you’re eager to learn and have a great attitude, this client embraces on the job learning.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Perl Tk: The label, button, and entry widgets
Week 138 Task 1 Workdays
item.description: Nice to see, Steven found time to blog about his solution. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Weekly Challenge 138
item.description: Simon is one of the few PWC members who always promote the weekly challenge on dev.to. Thank you for supporting us.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 138: Split Work
item.description: I liked how Roger picked Raku to talk about the Workdays task. Great example of code reuse. As always, thank you for your support and encouragement.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 138
item.description: Luis blog main attraction for me is the Perl one liner. It is not always easy to read but I like to challenge myself at times. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 138: split working days
item.description: Luca once again shares Raku and bonus solutions in PostgreSQL. Luca keeps things simple and I find it easy to follow. Thanks for sharing your knowledge.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 138: Workdays and Split Number
item.description: A very compact solutions in Perl and Raku as always by Laurent. He always get to the point without wasting time. Keep up the great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge #138
item.description: James observation about the task is very unique. He has the ability to get to the bottom of each task and shares the knowledge. You really don't want to miss out. Thank you for sharing your experience with us.

item.title: PWC138 - Split Number
item.description: A very interesting approach to the 'Split Number' task. I had to read the text twice to understand the flow. I loved the logic, something to keep in mind.

item.title: PWC138 - Workdays
item.description: Flavio using 'subset' of Raku is nice and clean. Nice mathematical hack to get the end result. You are a great story teller too. Thanks for entertaining us every week.

item.title: I Thank You For The Days: The Weekly Challenge #138
item.description: What I like about Dave's blog is that he not only discuss the task but also gives bonus material related to the task. Incredible. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: CY's Take on The Weekly Challenge #138 Task 1 and Some Previous Tasks on Calendar Date
item.description: Cheok-Yin is back with cool blog, collections of more than just one week. I loved the narrations. Keep it up great work.

item.title: The Workdays are Numbered with Raku (and Perl)
item.description: Arne is one of the PWC members who I follow when it comes to Raku programming. His style of blogging apt for any new learner. Thank you for everything.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 138: Split Number
item.description: Abigail use of mathematical formula is fscinating. And then getting that translated into a subroutine is amazing. Thanks for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 138: Workdays
item.description: Abigail's blog has a nice bonus, I noticed, where you can live demo the solution. Really cool. Thanks for the support and encouragement.

item.title: Meet The Champion - Paulo Custodio
item.description: Get to know about Paulo Custodio.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 138
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Workdays" and "Split Number" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 139
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "JortSort" and "Long Primes". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: I finally start to translate Japanese Perl Zemi to English
item.description: Perl Zemi is Japanese Perl Tutorial site which is well known and red in Japan.

item.title: I made a calculator
item.description: Build calculator using wxGlade.

item.title: DBD::Oracle
item.description: Installing DBD::Oracle in Perl

item.title: A dream resyntaxed
item.description: Damian's take on the subject Curtis spoke about in his latest blog.

item.title: Language Design Consistency
item.description: As we know, Curtis and his team working on Corinna, we keep getting regular updates. The latest blog talking about design consistency.

item.title: My Favorite (?) Warnings - Ex-Warnings
item.description: Please checkout Tom's another favourite.

item.title: Taming the Moose: Classing up Perl attributes
item.description: Find out ways to tame a Moose, thanks to Mark.

item.title: Perl OpenAPI with Mojolicious
item.description: Find out the power of OpenAPI.

item.title: Perl LDAP
item.description: Cool mix of LDAP and Perl.

item.title: Processing dates and times with Perl
item.description: I always miss Dave's blog but this time I made sure you all get the benefit of his writings. It is great blog talking about different CPAN modules dealing with Date in general.

item.title: open invitation to participate in Perl-OpenMP on Github
item.description: Please do join Perl-OpenMP invitation.

item.title: The ephemeral miniconf
item.description: The Ephemeral Miniconf is planned on thursday 18th of november 2021.

item.title: #538 - Are you Perl blogger?
item.description:
Hi there

Going back to the editorial of last week edition of weekly newsletter, it is still there in my head asking many questions. It is universal fact, Perl is no longer the favourite language among the youths in the college these days. I remember when I was first introduced to Perl in 1999, it was the most popular language. Being a Perl fan, I feel it is my responsibility to bring Perl back to discussion table. One way to do is to talk about Perl based project and share with audience of others language. I have noticed not many people blog about Perl as they used to in the past. Talking about blogs, I would like to thank The Weekly Challenge team for spreading the power of Perl. For record, in the last 138 weeks, the team have created and shared over 2000 blogs. I used to blog regularly in the past but now a days I hardly find time. Having said, I still do monthly report blog where I talk about Perl and other projects. I find doing live video is less time consuming than writing a blog. I did it for sometimes and then I stopped that as well, sorry. You can take a look my YouTube Channel if you fancy. I came across series of videos by Gabor Szabo teaching Perl. It is great source for someone new to Perl and explore with live action.

I remember, Dave Cross, wrote a blog talking about something not many people would speak about. I personally agree with him fully and believe knowing more than one programming languages help you as a programmer.I can tell from my own experience, I picked up Raku last year while participating the weekly challenge. Whatever little I know about Raku till date, I can tell it has helped me a lot. I use that knowledge to write better Perl program. Recently I started doing Python as well just the basics for now. So the question is, does knowing Raku or Python make me any less Perl programmer? I am still Perl programmer and all thought process still follow Perl rules. Perl is my first love and will remain so rest of my life. Even today, after more than 22 years, I find features that I never knew existed before, specially in the field of regex. I would like to give credits to Abigail for sharing the magical regex in Perl as part of his weekly contributions.

While talking about blog, how can I miss those who are doing great service on a regular basis? I would like to thank Flavio Poletti for blogging every day for months now. Also there is another name, Mark Gardner who does weekly blog. Similarly we have weekly stats by Miguel Prz.

Enjoy the rest of the newsletter.
